definition: to try one's luck/to leave sth to chance
to touch/to meet with/to bump
to move/to transport/to use/to apply/fortune/luck/fate
gas/air/smell/weather/to make angry/to annoy/to get angry/vital energy/qi

sentences.english: But we dare not press our luck.
sentences.chinese: 但是我們不敢再碰運氣了。

sentences.english: The doctor decided to chance his arms and try to write a book on medicine.
sentences.chinese: 這個醫生決定碰碰運氣，試着寫一本關於醫藥的書。

sentences.english: Your husband always planned ahead, Lamborghini spyder smartphone chine, he left nothing to chance.
sentences.chinese: 你的丈夫總是提前計劃，他做事從來不碰運氣。

sentences.english: I was a young man and I felt the challenge of England would be good for me.
sentences.chinese: 我還年輕，覺得到英格蘭去碰碰運氣也不錯。

sentences.english: They moved there to try their fortune.
sentences.chinese: 他們搬往那裏去碰碰運氣。

sentences.english: He tried his fortune in another city.
sentences.chinese: 他在另一個城市碰碰運氣。

sentences.english: Lets take a chance on the weather and hold the party outdoors.
sentences.chinese: 讓我們在天氣方面碰碰運氣，在戶外舉辦聚會吧。

sentences.english: The police may catch me, but I'll chance it.
sentences.chinese: 警察有可能抓住我，但我要碰碰運氣。

sentences.english: He went to Chicago to try his luck in the World's Fair.
sentences.chinese: 他去芝加哥的世界博覽會去碰碰運氣。

sentences.english: Research shows the average person barely does any better than chance.
sentences.chinese: 研究顯示，一般人識破謊言的本事不比碰運氣強多少。

sentences.english: It's now or never, shall we chance it?
sentences.chinese: 機不可失，時不再來。咱們要不要碰碰運氣？

sentences.english: A mountain climber can't afford to take chances with inferior equipment.
sentences.chinese: 一個爬山運動員不能用較劣的裝備去冒險碰運氣。

sentences.english: I said I'd take my chances and asked him to put it in the showroom.
sentences.chinese: 我說，碰碰運氣吧，並請求他將車放在展示廳內。

sentences.english: Why don't you go and buy a lottery ticket. Take your chance.
sentences.chinese: 你幹嗎不去買張彩票啊？也碰碰運氣。

sentences.english: It was cloudy outside, but she chanced it without her raincoat.
sentences.chinese: 外面天多雲，但是她想不帶雨衣碰碰運氣。

sentences.english: Would you like to try your luck?

definition: luck (in gambling)
to make a detour/to take the long route
lit. flower viewing from horseback (idiom); fig. superficial understanding from cursory observation/to make a quick judgment based on inadequate information
to eat one's fill/to be full
to have one's spirits dampened/to feel disappointed
to pay money
this side/here
depending on the situation
to drive a cart
to beat down the price/to haggle/to slash one's prices
distant/far-flung
to overdose on supplementary medicine/to cram too hard
to order dishes (in a restaurant)
When you enter a village, follow the local customs (idiom); do as the natives do/When in Rome, do as the Romans do
to keep an appointment
to return to the same school and repeat a course from which one has already graduated, as a result of failing to get good enough results to progress to one's desired higher-level school
